transcripts.text: Who paid for it?  Who paid for it?  dividing conqueror.

You see a lot of people out here talking about tearing something down that they don't even know the history of.  If you're going to protest something, protest turning it back the way it was facing, which was the Capitol.  That's the way that statue was facing.  Y'all don't even know the history of this statue, but you want to tear it down because you are offended.

Listen, and let me say one other thing.  to all of the people that live in the community.  But I work for myself.  I'm nobody to do nothing.  I do this for myself.  And for all the people in the community that's so upset, why didn't you clean this statue up?  Why haven't you cleaned up around it, community?  You're so upset and you want to tear it down, but you won't even clean up around it.  Okay?  It don't matter.
What is your message to Black Lives Matter protesters who are demanding to tear this down and they are basically...

I say the Black Lives Matter people are full of shit.  And the reason I say they're full of shit, because their money ain't saying Black Lives Matter.  You coming out here, you want to tear down statues, but how much of this black history of D.C.  do you really know?  If black lives really matter.  You know, how much of this history have you tried to learn about Washington,  D.C.?  Because we got black history that's dying on the vine, sir, right here in Washington, D.C So if black lives really matter, what does your money say?
What would you say, sir, is just your overall goal today for the reason you came out here today?  Just your overall goal.  What's the message you want to send?

It is to bring some historical context to this conversation.  I understand that from reading your current history that there are some who want to bring down some monuments.  And I certainly understand that.  The Confederate monuments.  When I gave a speech in 1865 in Maryland, I said to them then, now that the monster of slavery is dead, let the shadow and the substance go down together and let them sleep forever in a common grave.  That's what I said to them.  And so if these monuments are still standing, then we have not put away those ideas.  Now, we should not, to use a phrase that you all might use, we should not throw out the baby with the bathwater.  This is the monument that we built.  Thank you, ma'am.  Cue your glass here.  So we should certainly be having a conversation.  That's why this monument was erected, to be a place where we could have conversations and ensure that we understand the history and appreciate our history and at the same time make sure that we're moving on to the future and the promise of the forefathers.  And we're invested in the Constitution.  Many of you, I don't know, how many of you feel like you have divested yourselves of the Constitution?
